- [Babish] Today we're
celebrating National Ice Cream Day

on July 18th by taking ice
cream to the next level
in an ice cream cake.
It's only fitting

that today's episode is
sponsored by Sensodyne,

the #1 dentist recommended
toothpaste for sensitive teeth.
If you have sensitive teeth,

subject of today's episode:
ice cream cake.
Let's get down to basics.
(upbeat music)
(casual music)

So for the ice cream layers
of our ice cream cake,

you could most certainly
buy your favorite ice cream,
let it defrost in the fridge

until it has the
consistency of soft serve,
and just use that.

But if you wanna make your
very own custard from scratch,
here's how you do it.
We've got 15 ounces of whole milk,

12 ounces of heavy cream,
and three ounces of sugar
that we're gonna bring to a bare simmer.

While that's coming up over
medium, medium-low heat,
we are separating out six large egg yolks
into a large, heat-proof bowl.
And for our vanilla custard,
we're gonna scrape out the contents
of one large vanilla bean,
tossing those delicious little seeds
and our vanilla bean carcass
into our nearly-simmering dairy.
Whisk that to combine,
and then back over to the egg yolks,
where, at the very last minute,

we're gonna add 3 3/4
ounces of granulated sugar,
and whisking until thick and ribbony.
We're doing this at the last minute

because if you let egg yolks
and sugar sit too long,

they can sort of scramble the
eggs and ruin your texture.
Now, when the milk, cream, sugar,
and vanilla mixture just starts to bubble,
we're gonna use it to temper our eggs.

That is, slowly ladle in
about half the mixture
while whisking constantly so as,
once again, not to scramble your eggs.
Kendall says I do this way too slowly,

so I don't know, maybe you
can do it a little faster.

But once you've added
about half the mixture,
it's safe to add it back to the pot,

once again, whisking
constantly, nice and slow.
And bring it back on over to the stovetop,
where we're gonna heat it,
once again whisking pretty constantly,
to a temperature of 180 degrees Fahrenheit

over a medium, medium-low flame.
Once you get her up there,

it's time to strain the mixture
through a fine-mesh sieve,
both to catch our vanilla pod
and any accidentally-scrambled bits,

and allow to cool
completely before churning.

We're also gonna do a
chocolate ice cream layer
to this cake.

Very similar recipe,
except for the addition of,
as you may have guessed, chocolate.
One ounce of cocoa powder

and a 1/2 teaspoon of
instant espresso powder

get tiny-whisked into our
6 3/4 ounces of sugar.
We are also finely chopping four ounces
of high-quality dark chocolate

with every intention of
melting it into our custard.

I forgot to divvy up
the cocoa-sugar mixture
between the egg yolks and the cream.
No big deal.

Just means we're really gonna
need that damp kitchen towel

wrapped around the base of
our bowl to keep it steady
as we repeat all the steps
for the vanilla ice cream verbatim.

Temper the egg yolks with half
the simmering dairy mixture.
Add it back to the pot.

Cook over a medium-low flame
until it hits a buck 80,
whisking pretty constantly the whole time.
But this time, once we get up to temp,

we are adding all of that
lovely chopped chocolate,

allowing it to gently
melt into our custard,
deepening its chocolate flavor.
Whisk until no chunks o' chocolate remain.
Add a teaspoon of vanilla, if you like.
And then, just like with the vanilla,

it's time to strain
through a fine-mesh sieve
and chill as quickly as possible.

Normally, that would mean at
least four hours in the fridge.
But because I don't wanna
spend all day making an ice cream cake,

I'm gonna speed things up
by virtue of an ice bath,

nestling my tub o'
custard in a big ol' bowl
filled with ice and water,
whisking occasionally to make sure
that it's getting cooled evenly

until it's nice and chilly,
about 42 degrees Fahrenheit.
Meanwhile, we can make our other stuff.
First, a simple caramel sauce.

8 1/2 ounces of sugar
and 2 1/2 ounces of water
are combined in a high-walled saute pan,
brought to a simmer without stirring,
and cooked over medium-high heat
until they reach a lovely amber color.
During this process,

you might notice tiny little
crystals starting to form

around the outside of
the bubbling mixture.
These are bad news

and a one-way ticket to
crystallizing your caramel.
The fix is simple:

keep a lid on your pot while
the caramel is cooking.

The humidity in the pot
will dissolve the crystals,

and you'll end up with
a nice, smooth caramel.

Once everything's a nice
amber golden-brown color,
we're gonna kill the heat

and carefully add two
ounces of unsalted butter
cut up into small pieces,

whisking to make sure
that it's fully melted.
A lot of people do cream and then butter,
but adding the butter first
helps cool things down a little bit

so the caramel doesn't
bubble as frighteningly
when you add the cream, four ounces of it,

a little bit at a time,
whisking constantly.

And by the time all the very
scary bubbles have receded,

you should have a nice,
smooth, creamy caramel.
Make sure you salt it generously.

Caramel without salt is like
a mustache without a kiss,
or however the old saying goes.
And set aside to cool completely
while we make us some candied peanuts.
You can definitely just buy these.
You don't need to make them.
But I wanted to show you guys an example
of when you want to encourage
rather than discourage crystallization.

We're combining five ounces of
sugar, three ounces of water,
and 10 ounces of roasted unsalted peanuts,
cooking over medium-high heat

and doing what you're never
supposed to do with caramel:

stirring rigorously, which
encourages crystallization,
as you're about to see.
The sugar's gonna start to seize up
and glue itself to the peanuts.
This is normally the point

at which you'd throw away
your caramel and start over,
but we're gonna keep cooking it
over medium, medium-low heat

until the sugar starts
to re-melt, caramelize,
and turn a lovely, toasty golden brown,

leaving us with some
old-timey-style candied peanuts
that you can definitely just buy
and don't need to make on your own.
But if you do, go ahead and spread 'em out
on a parchment-lined baking sheet
and allow them to cool completely

before putting them to use
in your ice cream cake.
I'm saving a bunch for garnish,

but I'm grabbing about cup,
cup and a half of these
and smashing 'em up in a zip-top bag,
dumping 'em into a bowl,
and combining them with our cooled caramel

to make a chewy, crunchy,
candy bar-like layer
in the center of our ice cream cake.
Now, we could stop the episode here.

You could just whip up
a bowl of this stuff
and eat it with a spoon,

and you'd be perfectly
happy with your life.
But whoever you're making this cake for

would be pretty disappointed
on their birthday,
so we must soldier on.
Next up, a chocolate caramel fudge

that comes straight from
Jess's family recipe book.
In a medium saucepan,

we are combining four
ounces of unsalted butter,
one 12-ounce can of evaporated milk,
five ounces of sugar,
and two ounces of bittersweet chocolate.
Then, we're bringing it to a simmer

and cooking for 10 to 15
minutes, which should yield

a smooth, creamy chocolate
fudge caramel thing
that freezes up beautifully
into a dense, chewy, flavorful layer.
Then, last but kind of first,
we have the base of our cake.

I've got about 12 ounces of
chocolate sandwich cookies
that I'm gonna pulse in a food processor
until reduced to a fine dust

and combine with three ounces
of melted unsalted butter.

This is gonna form a super
easy crunchy cookie base
for our cake.
Now finally, to assemble,
I got myself a 10-inch springform pan,
which I'm going to line with acetate film.
You do not have to do this
if you plan on frosting your cake
with whipped cream or whatever,

but if you want a nice,
clean, sharp exterior

that needs no frosting,
this is your ticket.
This stuff's available for cheap online
and makes for beautiful cakes.
So, to finally start building our cake,
we're gonna dump our cookie-butter mixture
into the bottom of the cake pan

and find a nice flat-bottom
thing, like this ramekin,

to press it firmly into
a flat, even layer.
Go ahead and pop this into the freezer

for about half an hour whilst
we commence to churning.

Now, once again, if you
bought your ice cream,

this is not a step that
you need to engage in.
Just let it defrost in the fridge
for half an hour to an hour,
beat it with a hand mixer

until it has the
consistency of soft serve,
and you're good to go.

But if you joined us in
making your own custard,
this is the time that we need to churn it

until it has the
consistency of soft serve,
which, after a quick taste test,

we can form into the
first layer of our cake.
It's as simple as dumping it in

and trying to smooth it out
as, uh, smoothly as possible

so that you end up with
nice, clean, even layers.
An offset spatula, bowl scraper,

or bench scraper are very
useful in this situation.
Once we've got it spread out evenly,
this guy's headed back into the freezer
for about an hour to firm up,
and then this is optionally
where you can add your secret channel
of chocolate caramel fudge.

You'll notice that I'm
digging a sort of ring
out of the ice cream,
and then it's into this ring
that I'm going to pipe our cooled fudge.
Top it up with your scooped-out ice cream,
and nobody'll even know that it's there.
Until they slice into it,
and that's, I mean, that's the whole idea.
Anyway, we're smoothing this guy back out
and dropping him back in the freezer
for at least another half hour,
just enough to firm up

so that we can add our layer
of candied peanut caramel.

I love the things I get to
say on this show sometimes.
Likewise, get that nice and super smooth.
Pop it back into the freezer
for another half hour to an hour,

during which time we can
churn our next ice cream.
Once churned, we can add it to the cake,

get it nice and smooth
just like the vanilla,

and that's it: the body
of our cake is done.
To ensure structural integrity,

we're gonna let it camp out
in the freezer overnight

before removing it,
decorating, and serving.
Speaking of decorating,

I'm gonna make a super
simple chocolate ganache,

one that will be liquid
at room temperature
but solidify once it hits the cake.
We're just finely chopping nine ounces
of high-quality dark chocolate,

covering with 6 1/2 ounces
of simmering heavy cream
in a heat-proof bowl,
covering, and letting sit for five minutes

before whisking into a
smooth chocolate ganache.

Now, if you didn't chop your
chocolate finely enough,

like me, you might find that
you still have some chunkers
floating around in there,

and the fix for that is to
place it over a double boiler
or a steaming pot of water

and let the gentle, steamy
heat melt the chocolate
the rest of the way.
Once you got that nice and smooth

and placed into a squeeze bottle
or piping bag of some kind,

it's time to lift it up,
let it drape for the camera,

maybe stick your finger under
there, grab yourself a sample.
Make sure it's not poisoned or anything.
Nope, no poison.

And then it's time to
crack this bad boy open.
Now I'm just using my hot, hot hands
to warm the sides of the springform pan.
If you did not use the acetate film,

you might wanna run a butter
knife around the outside
to separate it from the cake pan.
Once you've done that,
things should pop open pretty easily,
revealing a nice, neat ice cream cake,

depending, of course, on

both of which I have very little.
Once you've removed the film,
because of all the butter in the crust,
it should slide pretty easily
onto a cake stand for decoration.

But like all cake-moving
processes, it's pretty harrowing.
Once you get it on there, though,

all there is left to do is
make it look pretty again,
something I'm not terribly good at.

so I would do more like seven

everything that you can imagine.

this doesn't look half bad.
